/COMMIT_MSG.message: Could you paste an example link for this? Or just your locally testing?

I didn't get first-hand logs when problem occured, and this problem is not expected to always happen。
I will wait for it happening again and file&submit the bug.
And as to you advices, I'll give them more consideration.
Thanks.

You can file a new neutron bug for this. And this nova bug is really a good case, you can follow that format to write the neutron bug details:
Description
===========
Steps to reproduce
==================
Expected result
===============
Actual result
=============
Environment
===========

See https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1603909. I'll paste this link in new patch set.

In our tempest, I just see the same problem happening.
For large set instance booting, I suggest create the port first, and if possible set the IP for the port prior to calling API. Then use these ports to create the instances.

nova boots instances with two types of `--nic`, specifing either a allocated port or a network from which nova-compute service will allocate ports for instances.

The former is what you suggested。
The latter one is where my issue exists, and It's quite a common user case.
Moving ports allocation operation forward to nova-scheduler or nova-conductor will lead to bottleneck, and thus triggering more problems, IMO.

No, nova does not need to do such ip/port allocation. My point is to create port with specified IP address first by your CLI/portal/console/UI, and then boot instance like this:
nova boot --nic port-id=<port-uuid> ...
Instance info_cache does not store these info in DB?

I mean, neutron server TIMEOUT happens while nova-compute waiting for a response. This leads to task `_build_and_run` aborted and rescheduled. In this case, nova-compute can never retrievs port uuid from response body(howerver, ports
can still eventually be allocated by neutron-server). And  so, newly selected compute nodes konow nothing about the ports. If ports identifiers are pre-generated, and ports are allocated with user-specified uuids, things will be different.

With this "user-specified port uuid", I'm not quite sure if nova can work properly as excepted. If nova-compute node-1 creates a port with uuid-1, and it fails to boot, re-schedule to next compute node-2. Something elusive I can image will be:
neutron still in port creating procesure (IPAM is time-consuming now), so node-2 may create it again, and probably fails due to conflicts of port uuid.
And two condition for node-1 to deal with the port when it get booting failure:
1. try to delete the port, there will be a race condition for node-2 to boot the instance. (delete may not work, since port can also not created.)
2. does not delete the port, because of the port-uuid conflict I mentioned above, this port can also remain when nova stop re-schedule. 

This leads to lots of work for nova to do:
1. nova needs a place to store all its interface port uuid
2. check if this port exist and then create or boot
3. what's the behavior of boot failure
4. re-schedule policy
...

neutron_lib/api/definitions/port.py.message: None is absolutely not acceptable. Port id is widely used for device names.
I agree with Liu.  Plus we can't just change the API like this anyways, something like this would need to be done in an extension so it's discoverable.

As I can see, validator with `type:uuid_or_none` supports:
1. user-specified port uuid
2. no user-specified port uuid. And port uuid will be assigned later(this is the current case).

Once created, port id will be populated and port id
is not allowed to be updated(i.e allow_put=False). When port identifiers appear as device names, It will still be OK.
'default' means the default value for 'id' attribute. 'default' here is unnecessary even if you allow to specify ID for a port as it can be handled in the logic of create_port.

nova.objects.fields.PCINUMAAffinityPolicy is an alias for the string type express as a nova enum

class PCINUMAAffinityPolicy(BaseNovaEnum):

    REQUIRED = "required"
    LEGACY = "legacy"
    PREFERRED = "preferred"

ALL = (REQUIRED, LEGACY, PREFERRED)

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/objects/fields.py#L716-L722

BaseNovaEnum is defeined as

class BaseNovaEnum(Enum):
    def __init__(self, **kwargs):
super(BaseNovaEnum, self).__init__(valid_values=self.__class__.ALL)

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/56eac06561bc843dcf7497e8b7ac3027f62544c1/nova/objects/fields.py#L716-L722

and the ovs enum filed is defied here
https://github.com/openstack/oslo.versionedobjects/blob/master/oslo_versionedobjects/fields.py#L311-L343

so at runtime this is technically a python string but it is validated as a instance of the filed type.
i could change this to string as it is a sting but then we loses the context that the sting must be a valid value of the enum defined by nova.objects.fields.PCINUMAAffinityPolicy

so we prefert teh extra spec value if set and fall back to the alais value if not.

so by defualt no change in behavior and you can opt in to the new behavior by updating the flavor/image so there is not upgrade impact
Ah, misunderstood this to be the alias in the config file. Yeah, this makes sense.

this is where the fallback happens for pci requests created by flavour alias.

if both affinity_policy and numa_policy are None then policy will be none and we will implicitly fallback to legacy.

so we use the affinity_policy if set, then fallback to the policy in the alias, then fall back to none which results in the legacy policy.

Does this mean that the numa policy from the config is overwritten by the config from the flavor or image?

If yes then we might have a problem. Overwriting config done my the admin in the config is OK from the flavor as flavor is also adminy thing. But allowing to overwrite the admin config from a user define image meta seems wrong.

I think the spec specified the expected behavior[1] as it is implemented above so my comment just to confirm that we are not overlooked this change in the spec review.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/683174/7/specs/ussuri/approved/vm-scoped-sriov-numa-affinity.rst@70

yes this is intentional, im not sure if others over looked it but i thought about this at some length.

the original spec only as in back in queens only allowed flavour and image extra properties but during the impemetion that was replaced with the alias approach.

the config done by the admin in the alias will only apply to alias based passthough and never applied to neutron sriov port since it does not use an alias.

so if we did not make the flavor and image override the config we would be in a situation where if you requested a VF via an alias it would have one behaviour but if we requested the same vf via a neutron port the image and flavour would have precedence.

i strongly considered deprecating support for expressing a numa_ploicy in the alais entirely but felt that was not required if the flavor or image took precedence.

if we think its a problem then i think we should revisit removing support for the config option and only support the flavour and image approach.

nova/compute/utils.py.message:
image_meta will be an object not a dict, so 'key in image_meta.properties' should raise an exception.

You want todo  hasattr(image_meta.properties, key)

The object supports __contains__ and provides the same semantics as SQLA. __contains__ returns True if the attribute is loaded. hasattr() will always return True because all fields are properties on the object, but it will also trigger a lazy-load in the process, which is not what you want of course.

So, using __contains__ is the right thing to do here.

You can't use hasattr here. You need to use __contains__. So:

 return any(key in image_meta.properties for key in hw_rescue_props)

Yeah I think that's what I was thinking so I'll likely follow up to change this to use CONF.host. And that coincides with how it works during confirm for same-cell resize:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/e937c5c6c47658e695b1e934b3d6e660dc6514ed/nova/compute/manager.py#L4343

This isn't for the user. At this point the instance is mapped to the target cell and that's where the confirmResize action was created by the API:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/e937c5c6c47658e695b1e934b3d6e660dc6514ed/nova/compute/api.py#L3637

So up to this point we have an action for this request ID in the target cell DB but when we call confirm_snapshot_based_resize_at_source in the source cell it uses the @wrap_instance_event decorator so it needs to be able to find an action in the source cell db for the given request ID to track the event.

Thinking back on this now, I wrote the compute method with the wrap_instance_event decorator before I refactored this code to use the EventReporter locally in conductor so I wouldn't have to copy and insert the compute_confirm_snapshot_based_resize_at_source event from the source to the target cell DB, so we could probably get away with dropping the wrap_instance_event decorator from confirm_snapshot_based_resize_at_source in the compute manager, but it's probably fine to leave it for auditing in case something fails in the compute and someone is trying to dig back out the source cell records.
Thanks for the detailed answer. I'm OK to keep the decorator there.
source instance will be hard deleted so it is not a problem to not doing this as a temporary mutation

Yup. And I realize this is a bit of gross tight coupling but I thought it might be weird to just use instance.flavor (as the old_flavor) directly in confirm_snapshot_based_resize_at_source when dropping the move claim on the source host.

This logic actually comes from finish_resize in the same-cell case:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/e937c5c6c47658e695b1e934b3d6e660dc6514ed/nova/compute/manager.py#L5453

So if we wanted to avoid this weirdness we could have the FinishResizeAtDestTask set and save this on the source cell instance so we don't have to do it in the confirm task.

useing virtio-scsi for ceph was documented and talked about at lenght a few years ago https://ceph.com/planet/more-recommendations-for-ceph-and-openstack/

upstream qemu has also shifted there deveopment to virtio-scsi so virtio-blk is becoming the legacy options at this point. i have spoken to kasyap at some point baout shoudl we change the default in nova however it has not yet been pressing enough to do. e.g. no customer asked for it.

Thanks for the info. Note I mentioned virtio-serial in the commit message.

In my testing I found that not all virtio devices need iommu, e.g. (IIRC) for mice it doesn't matter. So I suspect we're OK for those cases too - I'll ask the SEV experts, but if not they could be handled as follow-ups.

Based on this reply from Jim, I think it is already handled correctly through LibvirtConfigGuestController:

> Channels of type 'virtio' use virtio-serial as a transport. See this old wiki for more info:

> https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Features/VirtioSerial
> 
> 
> Virtio-Serial Summary
> 
> 
> This feature modifies the current single-port virtio-console device to guests running on top of qemu and kvm. It exposes multiple ports to the guest in the form of simple char devices for simple IO between the guest and host userspaces.

> So the channel just consumes a port on the virtio-serial controller, which should already have the iommu='on' setting. E.g. a VM with the following XML config

>      <controller type='virtio-serial'>
>        <driver iommu='on'/>
>      </controller>
>      <channel type='unix'>
>        <target type='virtio' name='org.qemu.guest_agent.0'/>
>      </channel>

> will have this qemu invocation: 

>   -device virtio-serial-pci,id=virtio-serial0,iommu_platform=on,bus=pci.5,addr=0x0 -device virtserialport,bus=virtio-serial0.0,nr=1,chardev=charchannel0,id=channel0,name=org.qemu.guest_agent.0

> Indeed this VM works fine for me and there are no problems interacting with the guest agent from the host.

I got a reply from Brijesh:

> All the virtio devices behind the PCI bus should have iommu_platform=on flag set for the SEV case. I believe qemu provides the iommu_platform flags for the following devices
> 
> 
> - virtio-serial 
> - virtio-blk 
> - virtio-scsi 
> - virtio-rng 
> - virtio-net 
> - virtio-balloon 
> - virtio-gpu 
> - virtio-vga 

I guess these are the qemu names, so I need to translate them into libvirt-ese.  As mentioned before, Nova does not use virtio-serial.  The other ones map to Nova config classes as follows:

    virtio-scsi     config.LibvirtConfigGuestController
    virtio-blk      config.LibvirtConfigGuestDisk
    virtio-net      config.LibvirtConfigGuestInterface
    virtio-rng      config.LibvirtConfigGuestRng
    virtio-balloon  config.LibvirtConfigMemoryBalloon

I *think* virtio-gpu and virtio-vga both map to config.LibvirtConfigGuestVideo but I'm not sure.  I found some web pages which suggest that virtio-gpu is enabled via

    <graphics type='spice'>
      <listen type='none'/>
      <gl enable='yes'/>
    </graphics>
    <video>
      <model type='virtio'/>
    </video>

in which case we should add

        config.LibvirtConfigGuestVideo: 'model',

to the virtio_attrs dict above.  Sean does that make sense to you?

Brijesh, you didn't mention the virtio channels which Sean refers to above.  Does this mean by implication that we don't need to worry about them?

yes so i added support for requesting virtio video model expcitly in train. before it was enabeld for arm but was not requestable directly.

as mentioned on irc as virtio-serial is used for the qemu guest agent i think that would also need to be handeled but we could fix that in a different patch.

@eric
my understandiung is that setting this driver option forces the device memory to allocated form DMA memory which is a limited resources on some systems that said in general i think it would not have other negitive sideffect if it was not needed. however the libvirt and qemu folk chose not to make it the defult so there may be a reason beyond that.


i dont think we would want to defualt to driver_iommu=true
as we run the risk of exausting DMA or DMA32 kenerl zones which are need for things like pci divice passthogh/sriov
i guess we should SEV to that list of things that requrie DMA mappale memroy.

the DMA32 region is a kernel memory zone that reserves memory below 4G for use by device DMA buffers as a lot of hardware cant adress memory above 4G or 32bit of adress space. so the DMA32 zone is very important to perserve however its not the only DMA memory available on the system. DPDK use hugepages as a form of DMA memory and general system memroy can be used as DMA memroy for non hardware devieces e.g. virtio devices.

the other thing about DMA memroy is i dont belive it can be swapped so it would have weired effect on over subscription.

@adam
if you added uses_virtio i would prefer it to a property that internally did the check rather then a value we had to set independently of the model or the type. as i said above i dont htink we should default to enabling the iommu as im not sure if we we could exhaust avialble DMA memory on the host. 

give its a resouce we can track but not contol we cant use placment or to even know in the schduler how much is free as we dont know how much each guest will need.

so only forcing dma memroy to be used when its need seams prudent. this is the change set that intoduced the iommu paratmets to virtio  device by they way. https://www.redhat.com/archives/libvir-list/2017-June/msg00407.html

based on https://www.redhat.com/archives/libvir-list/2017-June/msg00416.html it can also be used on the file system elemtn when you are passing a folder on teh host to the guset but i dont think we use that in nova so you hsould not have to deal with it but yes apparently this can be set on a lot of different devices.

> that iommu wasn't needed in all cases.

Right, but does it do any *harm* if it's not needed? Point of my whack-a-mole comment being that, if not, you'd be covered, vs. trying to track down all the specific cases where it *is* needed (esp. future ones you don't know about yet).

 > Also something seemed
 > slightly evil about relying on introspection.

What you've got is arguably way more introspect-y.

> > that iommu wasn't needed in all cases.
 > 
 > Right, but does it do any *harm* if it's not needed?

Like I already said, maybe not.  I don't know.

 > Point of my whack-a-mole comment being that, if not, you'd be covered, vs. trying to track down all the specific cases where it *is* needed (esp. future ones you don't know about yet).

Sure.

 > > Also something seemed slightly evil about relying on introspection.
 > 
 > What you've got is arguably way more introspect-y.

*Way* more, really?  Yeah, that's definitely arguable ;-)  Use of hasattr is by definition introspection, whereas the getattr and .__class__ here are just allowing the syntactic sugar of allowing attribute lookup via the values of the dict.  They could easily be removed without changing the logic, as Stephen previously proposed here:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/644565/53/nova/virt/libvirt/designer.py@213

IMHO checking class membership is definitely less introspect-y than checking whether an object has an attribute.

But anyway, Stephen's second proposal at that link of adding a 'uses_virtio' seems a lot nicer, so maybe I'll switch it to do that.

I think I actually had it doing that at one point, and then found that iommu wasn't needed in all cases.  Also something seemed slightly evil about relying on introspection.  But maybe it wouldn't have done any harm after all.

nova/compute/api.py.message: Nit: *No* virt backend can do this, because if the compute host is down we'll fail before executing any virt driver code.
I wasn't sure if the VMWare or Hyper-V backends had multiple n-cpu services for the same cluster so went with most. Happy to reword if they would also fail.

No. It used to be the other way round, though: 1 compute could handle multiple clusters. I think we ditched that, although I wouldn't swear to it. If the compute's down, though, we don't get as far as the driver code.

Why are we ignoring forced_down here? If we're going to ignore forced_down I think we need:

1. A comment explaining why, given that we don't ignore it anywhere else afaict.
2. A functional test of some sort to ensure that there isn't already anything else which would cause a failure if the source compute is down.

However, reading the original spec I don't think we should ignore it:

https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/liberty/implemented/mark-host-down.html

IIUC, forced_down was added so that an HA system doesn't have to wait for heartbeat expiry after it fenced the host. IOW, forced_down means it's really down, but heartbeat may not have noticed yet.

> > Why are we ignoring forced_down here? If we're going to ignore
 > > forced_down I think we need:
 > >
 > > 1. A comment explaining why, given that we don't ignore it
 > anywhere
 > > else afaict.
 > 
 > ACK
 > 
 > > 2. A functional test of some sort to ensure that there isn't
 > > already anything else which would cause a failure if the source
 > > compute is down.
 > 
 > I'm not entirely sure what you're asking for here. There's a
 > plethora of functional tests that would already exercise this with
 > the default of False. Do you specifically want one with it set to
 > True?

I don't think this is a thing, because I think we should just remove it (see below), but assuming we don't remove it: this check assumes that resize currently works when the compute host is forced_down, but does it? If there's anything in the call chain we haven't thought of, or which anybody adds in the future, which checks service status before calling resize then this would be invalid. I think you'd need a functional test for something like that.

...or just delete it, which I think is the correct option anyway.

 > 
 > > However, reading the original spec I don't think we should ignore
 > > it:
 > >
 > > https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/liberty/implemented/mark-host-down.html
 > >
 > > IIUC, forced_down was added so that an HA system doesn't have to
 > > wait for heartbeat expiry after it fenced the host. IOW,
 > > forced_down means it's really down, but heartbeat may not have
 > > noticed yet.
 > 
 > My understanding was that the initial use case was just a shortcut
 > to allow for quick evacuations, putting the onus on the operator to
 > fence the host. I can't recall where this came up but I'm sure I
 > was told that since then operators have also started live migrating
 > from forced_down hosts where n-cpu remains up and that's the use
 > case I wanted to allow by ignoring the flag here.
 > 
 > Happy to drop this if it's controversial.

I'd be interested to see that discussion, but based on the original spec that would be an incorrect use of forced_down. We don't permit evacuate from a compute host which isn't down because the VMs might still be running. If you call forced_down you're asserting that they're definitely not running, so how can you live migrate?

I think it's simpler all round not to ignore it.

> Why are we ignoring forced_down here? If we're going to ignore
 > forced_down I think we need:
 > 
 > 1. A comment explaining why, given that we don't ignore it anywhere
 > else afaict.

ACK

 > 2. A functional test of some sort to ensure that there isn't
 > already anything else which would cause a failure if the source
 > compute is down.

I'm not entirely sure what you're asking for here. There's a plethora of functional tests that would already exercise this with the default of False. Do you specifically want one with it set to True? 

 > However, reading the original spec I don't think we should ignore
 > it:
 > 
 > https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/liberty/implemented/mark-host-down.html
 > 
 > IIUC, forced_down was added so that an HA system doesn't have to
 > wait for heartbeat expiry after it fenced the host. IOW,
 > forced_down means it's really down, but heartbeat may not have
 > noticed yet.

My understanding was that the initial use case was just a shortcut to allow for quick evacuations, putting the onus on the operator to fence the host. I can't recall where this came up but I'm sure I was told that since then operators have also started live migrating from forced_down hosts where n-cpu remains up and that's the use case I wanted to allow by ignoring the flag here.

Happy to drop this if it's controversial.

I thought both W503 and W504 were off by default in recent flake8?  I guess W503 wasn't disabled in the version you were working with or you wouldn't have included the ignore here. cyborg/common/nova_client.py.message: You can put links like this all on one line and ask pep8 to give it a pass by putting a " # noqa" comment at the end of the line.

IIUC it would look something like this:

 code = response.json()['events'][i]['code']
 if code == 422:
     LOG...("Nova won, no event necessary")
     return True
 else:
     LOG...("Couldn't fire event! Got code %d.", code)
     return False

Note the [i]. As currently written, you're always sending exactly one event, so it'll be [0]. But (and I think we've talked about this before) the names/interfaces of your internal methods imply that that might not always be the case. So you either need for this method to be written with a loop and granular returns to account properly for multiple events, or you should refactor/rename the other methods to make it clear that there's only ever going to be one.
We're fixing bug 1855752 via https://review.opendev.org/698037 to make this behave as we expected/thought.

> (BTW, I still feel strongly that you should do the "cyborg only
 > uses one event" refactor regardless.)

I see you did this in PS3, ++

> Cyborg sends only one event (for multiple ARQs of a single VM) but
 > the os-server-external-events API takes an array of events as part
 > of its interface [1].

I get that. That's my point. The methods you have here are kind of mixed as to whether they appear to expect/emit one or multiple elements in the array. They should be consistent, for readability/maintainability. If I were doing it, everything would be single-element until you actually do the POST. _send_events(self, events) would be _send_event(self, event), and L35 would do

 body = {"events": [event]}

That way it's not surprising when, later in the method, you say:

 # We only sent one event, so there's only one in the response
 resp_event = response.json()['events'][0]

 > Also, the response is HTTP 404, and has no 'events' key:

This isn't the condition we were going for. HTTP 404 means the instance for which you were trying to send events doesn't exist. That *should* be a failure here, because the instance should exist when the bind occurs.

The condition we want to allow is HTTP 207 where the *event* code for the (single) event is 422.

More in PS2...

Cyborg sends only one event (for multiple ARQs of a single VM) but the os-server-external-events API takes an array of events as part of its interface [1]. 

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=run-events-detail

Also, the response is HTTP 404, and has no 'events' key:

 {'cookies': <<class 'requests.cookies.RequestsCookieJar'>[]>,
  '_content': '
    {"itemNotFound": 
      {"message": "No instances found for any event", "code": 404}
    }',
  'headers': {
     'Content-Length': '78',
     'x-compute-request-id': 'req-83a667c8-3deb-4f71-8dbd-6d2f0fb7a428',
     'Vary': 'OpenStack-API-Version,X-OpenStack-Nova-API-Version',
     'Server': 'Apache/2.4.6 (CentOS) OpenSSL/1.0.2k-fips mod_wsgi/3.4 Python/2.7.5',
     'OpenStack-API-Version': 'compute 2.82',
     'Connection': 'close',
     'X-OpenStack-Nova-API-Version': '2.82',
     'Date': 'Sun, 08 Dec 2019 01:03:20 GMT',
     'Content-Type': 'application/json; charset=UTF-8',
     'x-openstack-request-id': 'req-83a667c8-3deb-4f71-8dbd-6d2f0fb7a428'},
     'url': u'http://172.25.103.180/compute/v2.1/os-server-external-events',
     'status_code': 404,
     '_content_consumed': True,
     'encoding': 'UTF-8',
     'request': <PreparedRequest [POST]>,
     'connection': <keystoneauth1.session.TCPKeepAliveAdapter object at 0x7fc25adf5410>,
     'elapsed': datetime.timedelta(0, 0, 124412),
     'raw': <urllib3.response.HTTPResponse object at 0x7fc25ae0c390>,
     'reason': 'Not Found',
     '_next': None,
     'history': []
 }

Nova API logs also show HTTP 404:

 Dec 07 17:03:20 otcfpga2 devstack@n-api.service[14529]: DEBUG 
nova.api.openstack.compute.server_external_events [None req-83a667c8-3deb-4f71-8dbd-6d2f0fb7a428 service nova] Unable to find a host for instance 00344b9f-b608-4248-8c50-b39210ef955e. Dropping event accelerator-requests-bound {{(pid=14538) create /opt/stack/nova/nova/api/openstack/compute/server_external_events.py:143}}
Dec 07 17:03:20 otcfpga2 devstack@n-api.service[14529]: INFO nova.api.openstack.wsgi [None req-83a667c8-3deb-4f71-8dbd-6d2f0fb7a428 service nova] HTTP exception thrown: No instances found for any event
Dec 07 17:03:20 otcfpga2 devstack@n-api.service[14529]: DEBUG nova.api.openstack.wsgi [None req-83a667c8-3deb-4f71-8dbd-6d2f0fb7a428 service nova] Returning 404 to user: No instances found for any event {{(pid=14538) __call__ /opt/stack/nova/nova/api/openstack/wsgi.py:941}}
Dec 07 17:03:20 otcfpga2 devstack@n-api.service[14529]: INFO nova.api.openstack.requestlog [None req-83a667c8-3deb-4f71-8dbd-6d2f0fb7a428 service nova] 172.25.103.180 "POST /compute/v2.1/os-server-external-events" status: 404 len: 78 microversion: 2.82 time: 0.119942

So, I have changed the implementation to use the 404 response body.

> This isn't the condition we were going for. HTTP 404 means the
 > instance for which you were trying to send events doesn't exist.
 > That *should* be a failure here, because the instance should exist
 > when the bind occurs.
 > 
 > The condition we want to allow is HTTP 207 where the *event* code
 > for the (single) event is 422.

When there is no host associated with an instance, Nova code enters [1], which sets the result to HTTP 207. 

*However*, in Line 146 [2], accepted_events is [], so an exception is raised with the message 'No instances found for any event', and that sends HTTP 404. That is a misleading message, but that is what we get today. It could be considered a bug: arguably, the code should have run the equivalent of lines 155-157 instead of throwing this exception.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/api/openstack/compute/server_external_events.py#L137

[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/api/openstack/compute/server_external_events.py#L146

Hm. I see, yes.

I thought it was you who reported that 207/422 originally...

...here [1]; but yeah, you only mentioned the debug log, not the final result.

Upon closer inspection, I agree you'll get 404 whether the instance is not yet assigned to a host, or has disappeared entirely. In the latter case, presumably you would want to clean up (unbind, free the accel, etc.).

The obvious hack that comes to mind is to do an additional instance query (GET /servers/{uuid}) and take the error path if that's 404. That gets you pretty close, but it's imperfect and racy as well.

Let's see if Dan has any better ideas...

(BTW, I still feel strongly that you should do the "cyborg only uses one event" refactor regardless.)

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/631244/46/nova/compute/manager.py@2627
Note that response.ok hits on anything <400, so your new code needs to go in this `if`, not the `else`. (FWIW the .ok is redundant; Response implements __bool__ which just answers self.ok.)
As noted in PS1 comments, you want the overall HTTP 404 to continue to raise, as that's a real, unexpected error condition

(unrelated) This is unreachable due to the foregoing exception.

That said, what's the actual interface of this method supposed to be on error? Return False or raise an exception? (A docstring wouldn't hurt.)

summary:
- I would refactor (which can be a different patch if you like) as noted in PS1 to make everything in this module clear that there's only one event being sent.
- The main logic should look something like:

 if response:
     if response.status_code == 207:
         # There's only one event, because we only sent one
         code = response.json()['events'][0]['code']
         if code == 422:
             LOG.info('Success: We won the race...')
             return True
         else:
             # 'status' is going to be 'failed', so not worth
             # including in the message :(
             LOG.error('Bad things: %d',  code)
             return False
     # "normal" 2xx success
     LOG.info("Successfully sent...")
     return True
 # 4xx/5xx failure
 LOG.error('Bad things (%d): %s', response.status_code, response.text)
 return False
